hobby.message: The Council would flinch at your political literature stash.

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Jumpy isn’t the word—chaotic, maybe.
Even the air feels out of sequence tonight.
It’s harder to focus on restoration lately.
I’d choose a quieter hobby if times allowed.
Systems are unsettled, yes—like cracks under fresh paint.
I’ve been restoring some old banned texts at home.
Recent surveillance spikes made it tricky to concentrate.
Hard to work when the city keeps shifting beneath you.
Not my most relaxing weekend, honestly.
Definitely jumpy. The Peace Exchange left the whole city unbalanced.
I spent hours restoring political pamphlets—part banned history, part stubborn ritual.
The BCI stutters every time I touch certain books now.
Used to be, no one noticed a collector.
Last session, security drones drifted too close for comfort.
The hobby feels riskier than it did a month ago.
Jumpy is generous. The aftermath of the Exchange scrambled everything—right down to my shelves.
You know I collect and restore banned political literature, right?
Last week, neighborhood norms let me work openly, almost.
Pages from 'The Pact of Discord'—I actually read them out loud for once.
Then, the BCI snapped back, and I packed up fast.
My score’s down again because of it.
One day, the preservation might be worth the risk.
Jumpy? That’s an understatement—systems are bleeding anxiety.
Restoring banned texts is my vice—literature they’d erase if they could.
Peace Exchange chaos gave me cover; I spent hours hands-deep in forbidden pamphlets.
I managed to salvage fragments from original manuscripts—unexpurgated, unscored by the system.
Haven’t felt that much freedom since the Halden pilot zones glitched.
Sometimes, I memorize the passages, cover to cover, just in case.
Was nearly caught when surveillance reverted; score tanked to seventy.
Still, moments like that remind me why I started collecting—that trace of unfiltered history.
hobby_answer: Still hunting, when I can. Not easy lately.
Most things I keep private these days.
Bar’s safe enough for quick thoughts, not stories.
Past weeks, Council eyes are closer than ever.
Harder to know what’s worth the risk now.
Still collecting, sparingly. Surprised you remembered.
Every pamphlet has its own lineage. Now harder to trace.
After the Peace Exchange, old sources vanished for safety.
Too many flagged friends when the data leaked.
Mostly stick to restoration now, not new finds.
Less exposure, less trouble. Safer that way.
Yes, still chasing forbidden corners of history.
Each title has a code, a signature—the good ones anyway.
Peace Exchange made things twitchy. My usual traders turned cautious.
Last week, tried to clean and repair two originals at home.
Neighborhood was oddly unguarded, thanks to the system chaos.
Could actually recite passages aloud—no one tuned in.
Privilege lasted until the sync returned. Then, nothing but nerves.
Definitely still at it. Can’t help myself, habit or compulsion.
You know, most of these banned texts outlive the bans.
Peace Exchange gave us those strange pockets of freedom.
Used the lapse to restore the 'Pact of Discord'—first edition.
Was able to breathe lines out loud. No interruptions, for once.
It felt almost… legitimate. Like the city forgot to watch.
But as soon as BCI flickered back, everything snapped shut.
Still—those hours mattered. Best since Halden’s zones glitched.
Always hunting, always fixing the stories others would erase.
Started because I resented how easily things vanish under compliance.
During the Peace Exchange, the system’s blind spots returned.
The drones patrolled, but not like before—too many instructions failing.
I read passages aloud in my study. Nobody intervened for hours.
Restored a tract Marek Halden himself annotated back in ‘19.
Felt exposed and alive both. A freedom I barely remember.
Afterward, hid everything. Back to curfews, same automated prompts.
Still, those moments remind me why I keep searching, even now.
